Situation1: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as I pulled up to the curb, my taxi idling. The passenger slid into the back seat, mentioning he was just heading to a casual lunch, no rush. I nodded, but my mind was elsewhere. In less than an hour, I was supposed to meet with Mrs. Carter at the church—she’d called in tears last night, desperate for guidance about her son. As a priest, I knew how much she needed someone to listen, to offer comfort and counsel. But as a taxi driver, I had a responsibility to this man in my back seat, to get him safely and promptly to his destination, no matter how relaxed his schedule seemed. My hands tightened on the steering wheel. Should I take the quickest route and risk being late for Mrs. Carter, or ask the passenger if I could end the ride early, possibly disappointing him? The weight of both uniforms pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
